11/1/2006 GBPG

Posted November 1, 2006

Beyer, Mabel

Mabel Beyer, 86, Green Bay, passed away Tuesday evening, Oct. 30, 2006, at a local nursing home. Born in Green Bay on Aug. 16, 1920, she is the daughter of the late Alice Delorit. Her mother died when Mabel was young and was raised by Grandma Tilly. She married Rudolph Unsinn and he preceded her in death in 1950.

On Dec. 4, 1954, she married William A. Beyer, and he preceded her in death on April 17, 2002. Mabel was an active and devoted member of Grace Presbyterian Church and held positions in several church organizations. She was a past member and past officer of the the V.F.W. Womens Auxilary and the Goldstar Mothers. Mabel enjoyed bowling, bingo, the Packers and especially times spent with her family.

Survived by her four daughters, Sandra Butterfield, Barbara (Ron) Derepkowski, Tina Beyer and Laurie Beyer, all of Green Bay; her buddy and constant companion, Shadow; six grandchildren, Robin Butterfield, Shawn (Patti) Butterfield, Todd Butterfield, Kelly Butterfield and special friend, Loren, Scott (Kris) Derepkowski, and Steven (Jodilynn) Derepkowski; 14 great grandchildren; brother-in-law and sisters-in-law, Anton and Betty Beyer, New Franken; Eva Unsinn, Green Bay.

Also preceded in death by two sons, Kenneth William Beyer, Michael Joseph Unsinn; one son-in-law, James Butterfield; one cousin, Bob Delorit; several brothers-in-law and sisters-in-law.

Visitation at MALCORE Funeral Home, University Avenue at Baird Street, from 4 to 8 p.m. Thursday. Friday visitation will continue at First United Presbyterian Church, 605 North Webster, east De Pere, from 10 a.m. until the time of the funeral. Funeral Friday 11 a.m. at First United Presbyterian Church by Pastor Dennis E. Mannering. Burial in Fort Howard Memorial Park.

Special thanks to Dr. Raymond Bachhuber, Bornemann Nursing Home (special nurses and CNA's on the North wing) and Unity Hospice.

Posted November 1, 2006

Gerke, Carl H.

On Oct. 30, 2006, our beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, Carl H. Gerke, passed on to eternal life surrounded by his family. He was born March 21, 1918, in West De Pere to the late Sheldon and Claire (Van DeCasteeler) Gerke.

Upon returning home at the end of World War II, he married his sweetheart, Rosemary Speaker, on Aug. 24, 1945, at St. Francis Church in East De Pere. Carl and Rosemary celebrated 61 years of marriage in August 2006.

Carl joined the National Guard Battery B in 1937. He was called to active duty in 1940 and served in the Pacific and Far East. He was recalled to active duty in 1950 and served during the Korean Conflict. Retiring in 1986 from sales, he enjoyed "snowbird" winters with his beloved wife in Florida and Arizona golfing to his heart's content.

Our father was a loving, patient and kind man. These virtues were his testimony of his daily walk with Christ. It was his understanding of Jesus' great love for Him and Jesus' love for mankind.

Carl is survived by his wife, Rosemary; his daughter, Jeanie (Dan) Manders; son, Michael (Pam) Gerke; grandchildren, Paul (Sadie) Vercauteren, Trista (Jason) Johnson, Jed (Dawn) Manders, all of Green Bay; Angela (Jamie) Carpenter, Arkansas; and Carl (Sanna) Manders, Beijing, China; great-grandchildren, Hailey Ann Johnson and Lane Carpenter.

Carl was preceded in death by his parents and his siblings Grace, Henry and Sheldon.

Visitation for Carl will be Thursday, Nov. 2, 2006, from 9:30 to 11 a.m. at Our Lady of Lourdes Parish Family, corner of Suburban Drive and Lourdes Avenue, De Pere. Mass of Christian Burial for Carl will be held at 11 a.m. at church with Fr. Tim Shillcox, O. Praem., officiating. Burial will be in Mt. Olivet, De Pere. Please visit www.ryanfh.com to send online condolences to the Gerke family.

The family would like to give a special thank you to the staff personnel at Rennes Health Center, St. Vincent sixth floor ICU and ninth floor for the loving care they provided Carl and his family.

Posted November 1, 2006

Lamers, Mildred M. "Milly"

Mildred M. Lamers "Milly," 80, died peacefully Oct. 30, 2006, at the St. Paul Home. She was born Sept. 9, 1926, in the town of Kaukauna, Wis., the daughter of the late Henry and Cecilia (Schampers) Bowers. On Nov. 21, 1946, Milly married Roy Lamers at St. Paul Catholic Church in Wrightstown. The couple farmed in the Hollandtown area until retiring in 1991. Roy preceded Milly in death on July 21, 2001. Milly was a member of St. Francis Catholic Church, Hollandtown. She enjoyed bowling, playing cards, traveling, the enjoyment of her flowers and tending to stray cats.

She is survived by her children, Pat (Corey) Kroll, Arizona; Jeanne (Dave) Sprangers, Combined Locks; Carol (Marty) Huss, Kaukauna; Bob (Nancy) Lamers, Kaukauna; Shirley (Don) Hoffman, Wrightstown; Kim (Jon) Ungemach, Greenfield; Betsy (John) Bittinger, Iron Mountain; 14 grandchildren, Tom Wouters, Brian (Annette) Kroll, Scott (Lisa) Sprangers, Janella (Jamie) Mader, Andy (Stacy) Huss, Dan (Jen) Lamers, Sarah (fiance, Dave Zouski) Lamers, Michelle (special friend, Skyler) Lamers, Tracy (Chris) Schroeder, Faye (Ben) Bader, Isral (special friend, Joanna) DeBruin, Rachel DeBruin, Brooke and Megan Bittinger; 14 great-grandchildren, Christina, Melissa, Kevin, Mickayla, Angelina and Andrew Mader, Adam and Emma Sprangers, Grace Huss, Peyton Schroeder, Haven Bader, Madison Wouters and Elizabeth and Andrew Kroll. She is further survived by sisters and brothers, Loraine (Jim) Shillcox, Mary Hermes, Arlene Blair, Bud (Eleanor) Bowers, Norman (Margaret) Bowers, Ann Bowers, Clarence (Nancy) Bowers, Lloyd (Mary Jane) Bowers and Rosanne (Bob) Bastian.

She was preceded in death by her brother, Lawrence Bowers; two brothers-in-law, Joe Hermes and Cletus Blair; and all the babies lost but never forgotten.

The Mass of Christian Burial for Milly will be 11 a.m. on Friday, Nov. 3, 2006, at ST. FRANCIS CATHOLIC CHURCH in Hollandtown with Fr. Jerry Pastors officiating. Friends will be received on Thursday at the Boettcher Family Funeral Home, 2401 Fieldcrest Drive, Kaukauna, from 4 p.m. until 8 p.m. with a parish prayer service at 7 p.m. and again on Friday from 9 a.m. until 10 a.m. at the funeral home. A memorial is being established in her name. Burial will follow Milly's service in the Parish Cemetery. The Boettcher Family Funeral Home, Kaukauna is assisting the family. 766-2099.

The family would like to extend their sincere thanks to the entire staff at St. Paul Elder Services, Isabelle and Dr. Desai. Your kindness will never be forgotten. May God bless you.

Posted November 1, 2006

Zimmerman, Sgt. Luke J.

Sgt. Luke J. Zimmerman, Luxemburg, was killed on Friday, Oct. 27, 2006, in Iraq. Luke was born May 28, 1982, in Green Bay, to Wesley Zimmerman and Claire (Denissen) Dombrowski. He was a graduate of Luxemburg-Casco High School, Class of 2000.

Luke is survived by his mother, Claire (Denissen) and Richard B. Dombrowski Jr., who filled the role of his absent biological father and treated Luke as his own child since Luke was in the third grade. He is further survived by his brother, Leonardo C. Zimmerman, Green Bay; and his two stepsisters, Brooke M. Dombrowski, Green Bay; and Toni L. Dombrowski, Little Suamico.

Also surviving are maternal grandfather, Alfred Denissen, Green Bay; uncles and aunts, Michael and Rose Denissen, Robert and Christine Belport, Green Bay; Scott and Linda Denissen, Kentucky; Dean and Julie Hoegger, Sturgeon Bay; Kurt and Monica Denissen, Milwaukee; Donald and Katherine Brosig, Green Bay; loving cousins, and stepgrandmother, Rosemary Gagnon, Green Bay.

He was preceded in death by his maternal grandmother, Mary Denissen, and paternal grandmother, Patricia Zimmerman.

Luke loved his family and was immensely proud of being in the U.S. Marine Corps. He always was so full of energy and pep, so kind and willing to help, share, and just goof off. He enjoyed his time just being Luke, from his video games, to his little corny trinkets, to all his activities outside the home.

He lettered in wrestling, track and cross country. Going to team state with his wrestling pals and also medaling in track at La Crosse with his exceptional relay teams. He also gave football a shot in his underclassman year and completed the season dutifully because quitting mid-season was not an accepted option (even though it wasn't his forte).

Luke worked tirelessly at Julie's Cafe all the while engaged in a full slate of extra-curricular sports. He never complained and rarely, if ever, missed his work assignment.

Luke was so committed to the Marine Corps that he made his mind up in the seventh grade. He joined the program for early enlistment and left almost immediately after graduation. He re-enlisted after his first four-year tour. He enjoyed his job at the U.S. Embassy in Austria. He then had 18 months left to serve while stationed at Quantico, Va., but wasn't able to accept other Marines doing what he felt Marines were supposed to do. So he selflessly volunteered to join the unit that was going to be deployed to Iraq. Luke enlisted in the infantry and expected to be a warrior, and wanted to live up to the standards of a man and a Marine. We believe he achieved those milestones. Luke was passionately known as "the mule" by his Marine comrades, and those who personally knew him can relate to that. Luke and his family kept all service members, and especially U.S. Marines, as equals. No one Marine was esteemed over another (maybe Chesty).

Luke was so proud to have received his Combat Action Ribbon and his Iraqi Campaign Service Medal. In addition to being decorated with a Purple Heart, Luke's service ribbons included the Marine Corps Good Conduct Medal with one star in lieu of a second award, War on Terrorism Service Medal, Navy Unit Commendation Navy/Marine Corps and the Navy Sea Service Deployment Ribbon with three Bronze Star Devices and the National Defense Service Medal.

Luke's parents and brother were blessed by the Lord to have him for 24-plus years. When notified, one of his mother's biggest worries was if other Marines got injured. Luke's parents would like to attempt to thank Steve and Julie Metzler and their sons, Scott, Troy, Greg and Eric for almost unofficially "adopting" Luke. They spent countless times with their buddy and co-worker. Luke loved, "The Metzlers" and the feeling was unequivocally reciprocal.

Special thanks also to Captain T.M. Mitchell, U.S.M.C. and Corporal Stigsell for doing an exceptional job in assisting Luke's mom with what the Marines do best  taking care of their own. Semper Fidelis. Pastor William Kamke and the parishioners of the Robinsonville Presbyterian Church of New Franken have been so kind, compassionate and accommodating.

Friends may call at Proko-Wall Funeral Home, 1630 E. Mason St., on Friday from 3 to 8 p.m. Visitation will continue on Saturday at Robinsonville Presbyterian Church, corner of Doris Road and County Road K, from 9 a.m. until the time of service. Funeral service 10:30 a.m. at the church with Pastor William Kamke officiating. Fittingly, Sergeant ZIMMERMAN, Luke J., U.S.M.C. will be laid to rest at Arlington National Cemetery, marking the last chapter in a noble young man's life. Affirmative, over and out.

In lieu of other expressions of sympathy, a memorial fund has been established in Luke's name. Please direct your donations to the Luke Zimmerman Scholarship fund, Bank of Luxemburg, Box 440 Luxemburg, WI 54217.

Posted November 1, 2006

Zirbel, Gerald Albert "Jerry"

Gerald Albert "Jerry" Zirbel, 62, Green Bay, passed away unexpectedly on Oct. 30, 2006. He was born on Feb. 24, 1944, in Sturgeon Bay, to the late Allen and Florence (Maccaux) Zirbel. He served in the United States Air Force for four years. He was employed by Georgia Pacific East until his retirement. He enjoyed woodworking, hunting and fishing.

Survivors include his two sons, Mark Zirbel and Daniel Zirbel; stepmother, Mary Zirbel; one brother, Jack (Paula) Zirbel; sister-in-law, Barbara Zirbel; close friend, Peg Wickman; nieces and nephews.

In addition to his parents, Jerry was preceded in death by one brother, Tom Zirbel.

Friends may call at Proko-Wall Funeral Home, 1630 E. Mason St., on Thursday from 1 to 6 p.m. Funeral service 6 p.m. at the funeral home with Rev. Dave Hatch officiating. Burial at Nicolet Memorial Gardens. Online condolences may be sent to the Zirbel family at www.prokowall.com.

Posted November 1, 2006

Lola L. Miller

Lola L. Miller, age 89, a resident of Shady Lane Nursing Care Center, Manitowoc, died Monday, Oct. 30, 2006, at Shady Lane.

She was born April 6, 1917, in Antigo, daughter of the late Frank and Kathrine (Zipperer) Reindl. On June 17, 1939, she married John J. Miller Jr. at St. Mary Catholic Church, Clarks Mills. He preceded her in death June 28, 1979.

Survivors include two sons and a daughter-in-law: Paul A. and Judith Miller, Manitowoc; David B. Miller, Reedsville; two daughters-in-law: Shirley Miller, Kellnersville; Linda Miller, Manitowoc; 11 grandchildren; 12 great-grandchildren; a sister: Dorothy Kronfrost, Mishicot; and two sisters-in-law: Lila Miller and Leona Miller, both of Manitowoc. Nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends also survive. She was also preceded in death by two sons: James and William Miller; three brothers and sisters-in-law: Bernard and Pearl Reindl, Elmer and Mary Reindl, Leonard and Dolores Reindl; one sister and two brothers-in-law: Gladys and Joseph Lemberger, Paul Kronfrost; two sisters-in-law and brothers-in-law: Margaret and Aaron Fischer; Florence and Frank Schiesl; and four brothers-in-law and a sister-in-law: Leonard and Frieda Miller, Ralph Miller, Edward Miller and Earl Miller.

Funeral services will be held at 10:30 a.m. Friday, Nov. 3, 2006, at St. Francis of Assisi, Grand Avenue Site, Manitowoc. Officiating at the Mass of Christian Burial will be the Rev. Dave Hoffman with entombment at Calvary Mausoleum Chapel, Manitowoc.

The family will greet relatives and friends at The Pfeffer Funeral Home & Cremation Care Center, Manitowoc, from 4 to 7 p.m. Thursday, Nov. 2, 2006, where a prayer service will conclude the visitation at 7 p.m. led by Deacon Alan Boeldt. Friends may also call on Friday morning, Nov. 3, 2006, at St. Francis of Assisi, Grand Avenue Site, Manitowoc, from 9:30 a.m. until the time of service at 10:30 a.m.

11/1/2006 Kewauanee Newspapers

Wed, Nov 1, 2006

Diane M. Martin (Mrs. Vernon)

Diane M. Martin (Mrs. Vernon), 67, Luxemburg, died Tuesday morning, October 24, 2006, at a Green Bay hospital, following a courageous 5 1Ú2-year battle with ovarian cancer.

She was born October 6, 1939, in New Franken, to the late Arthur A. and Syra (Conard) Ronsman.

On May 14, 1960, she married Vernon Martin at St. Hubert Church, Sugar Bush. For the past 25 years, she was employed with Parkview Manor Health and Rehabilitation Center, Green Bay. She was a member of the Catholic Knights and St. Mary Christian Mothers Society. Her enjoyments included shopping, travel, gambling, cooking, camping and spending time with her family and friends.

Survivors include her husband of 46 years, Vernon; and their four children, Brenda (Paul) Hunsader, Mike (Kristi) Martin, all of Green Bay; Linda (Mark) Joniaux, Cheri (Pete) Kline, all of Luxemburg; 12 grandchildren, Kyle and Amy Hunsader, Kaylen, Mariah and Connor Martin, Ashley, Kristin, Kelsey and Logan Joniaux, Marissa, Courtney and Adam Kline; one brother and two sisters-in-law, Dale and Rose Ronsman, Green Bay; Bonnie Ronsman, New Franken; three brothers-in-law and four sisters-in-law, John and Charmaine Martin, Donna Berger, Marilyn and Jim Rank, Terri and Wally Nemetz, all of Luxemburg; many nieces, nephews and friends.

Diane was preceded in death by, an infant twin sister; one brother, Roger Ronsman; two brothers-in-law, Don Berger and Joe Martin; father-in-law and mother-in-law, Peter and Anna Martin.

Friends called at the McMAHON FUNERAL HOME, LUXEMBURG, from 3 to 8 p.m. Thursday, October 26. Prayer service was held at 7 pm. Visitation continued after 9:30 a.m. to 10:45 a.m. Friday at St. Mary Church, Luxemburg. Funeral service was held at 11 a.m. Friday at the church, with Rev. Milton Suess officiating. Entombment was in the Shrine of The Good Shepherd Mausoleum.

In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund has been established in Diane's name.

11/2/2006 GBPG

Posted November 2, 2006

Conard, Mrs. Richard (Gladys)

Our wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, Mrs. Richard (Gladys) Conard, 88, New Franken, went to her eternal rest on Wednesday, Nov. 1, 2006, while a resident at Fred and Maime's. Born on Dec. 10, 1917, in Tonet, she is the daughter of the late Norbert and Julia (Laurent) Delcore. On Oct. 11, 1938, she married Harvey Conard, and he preceded her in death on June 25, 1971.

On Oct. 18, 1974, she married Richard Conard at St. Joseph Church in Champion. Gladys and Richard recently celebrated their 32nd wedding anniversary. Gladys farmed all of her life in the town of Scott, working side by side with Harvey, then Richard until they retired in 1982. She loved to bake, especially Belgian pies and chocolate chip cookies. As devoted Catholics, Gladys and Richard attended daily Mass at St. Joseph's Church and at the Robinsonville Chapel. She enjoyed playing Cuyoo with friends and neighbors. Gladys was the happiest when her family came to visit, especially all the little great-grandchildren. The grandchildren knew that they could never leave "grammas'" house without a pocket full of candy. "One for daddy, one for tomorrow," she would say.

Gladys will be forever remembered by her husband, Richard; two sons, one daughter, seven grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren, and six stepgreat-grandchildren; Ron and Sue Conard, and their sons, Paul (Barbara) Conard and their children, Cody, Kaitlyn, and Chelsea; Brian (Barbara) Conard and their daughters, Emily and Elizabeth; Mike (Becky) Conard and their children, Anna and William; Gary and Helen Conard and their son, Dave (Angie) Conard, his stepdaughters Samantha, Amanda and Miranda; Pat Dorner and special friend, Dale Verhagen. Pat's children, Cindy (Mike) Conard, and her stepsons Kyle, Andy and Adam; Tammy (Ken Jr.) Lemberger, and their children, K.J. and Kendra; Randy Dorner and his special friend, Jenna Mueller; sister-in-law, Lavern Conard; many nieces and nephews.

She was preceded in death by her first husband, Harvey; parents; four sisters, Mary (Fred) Dalebroux, Laura (Joe) Prevost, Lillian (Eddie) Everard; one brother, Fred (Mamie) Delcore; one infant sister, Irene; two brothers-in-law and one sister-in-law, Mabel (Henry) Strebel and Elmer Conard.

Visitation at MALCORE Funeral Home, University Avenue at Baird Street, Friday, from 3 to 8 p.m. Parish wake service 7 p.m. at the funeral home by pastoral assistant Pat Ratajczak. A rosary will follow at the funeral home by Bev Paye. Visitation will continue Saturday at St. Joseph, Champion, 5996 County Road K, from 9 a.m. until the time of the Mass. Mass of Christian Burial 10:30 a.m. Saturday at St. Joseph, Champion, with Rev. Dean Dombrowski officiating. Entombment at Allouez Chapel Mausoleum. Please visit malcorefuneralhome .com to send online condolences or share memories with the Conard family.

The family would like to extend a special thanks to Glady's niece, Sharon Depeau, for the exceptional personal attention she gave to Gladys during her illness. God bless Sharon and all of the wonderful staff at Fred and Mamie's for the care and compassion that they gave to Gladys, Richard, and the entire family.

Posted November 2, 2006

Triatik, Jeffery

Jeffrey (Jeff) Triatik, 29, Green Bay, died unexpectedly from a seizure, November 1, 2006, at a local CBRF.

Born in Green Bay, he is the son of Thomas Triatik and Carol (Peters) Triatik. Jeff spent most of his younger school years in the Green Bay School system. He was currently employed at Red Lobster in Green Bay and also at ASPIRO. Jeff enjoyed Special Olympics where he was very proud of his accomplishments and awards. He enjoyed swimming, bowling, basketball, computer games, special outings with his friends at ASPIRO and Oaks Family Care Center. Jeff was very energetic, outgoing, helpful, curious, loved meeting people, and had a heart of gold.

Survived by his mother, Carol Triatik, Green Bay; father and stepmother, Thomas Triatik and Bonnie Dennis, Sobieski; two sisters, Jennifer (David) Rudnik, Laurel Triatik, all of Milwaukee; paternal grandmother, Marian Triatik, Fond du Lac; two step sisters Rene (Todd) Smits, Kaukauna; Jill (Chad) Raisleger, Green Bay; uncles and aunts, Norman (Sandra) Peters Jr., Suamico; David (Kathy) Triatik, Malone, Wis.; Cathy (Rodney) Erdmann, Fond du Lac; Jim (Holly) Triatik, Fitchburg; Patti Tosh, Fond du Lac; many nieces, nephews, cousins, other relatives and friends.

Preceded in death by his maternal grandparents, Norman and Margaret Peters Sr; paternal grandfather, Fred Triatik.

Friends may call at WEST MASON MALCORE Funeral Home, 1530 West Mason Street, from 9 a.m. Saturday, until the time of the funeral. Funeral, Saturday 11 a.m., at the funeral home with Pastor Paul Garrison presiding. Burial in Suamico Cemetery.

A memorial fund has been established at the funeral home in his memory.

Special thanks to the Oaks Family Care Center.

Posted November 3, 2006

Albert, Thelma F.

Thelma F. Albert, 102, De Pere, passed away late Sunday evening, Oct. 29, 2006. She married Clarence Albert; he passed away on June 25, 1979. Thelma was a longtime active member of St. Anne's Episcopal Church where she served in the Women's Guild and Elderberries Group. She was a member of the Order of Eastern Star, Charles A. Lawton Chapter #270; Green Bay/De Pere Antiquarian Society and the De Pere Women's Club.

Thelma is survived by her two children, Beverly Sommerfield, De Pere; Thomas (Mary Kay Stevenson) Albert, Fredricksburg, Va.; six grandchildren; two great-grandchildren.

Family and friends may call on Monday, Nov. 6, 2006, at St. Anne's Episcopal Church, 347 S. Libal St., De Pere, after 4 p.m. Funeral 6:30 p.m. with the Rev. Seth G. Richmond officiating. Entombment in the Shrine of the Good Shepherd Mausoleum. Cotter Funeral Home, De Pere is assisting the family with arrangements.

A special thank you to the staff of Birch Creek for their loving care and concern given to Thelma.

In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund for St. Anne's Episcopal Church has been established.

Posted November 3, 2006

Ebben, Marcella "Sally" Clara

Sally Ebben, 92, passed away Wednesday, November 1, 2006, while in the care of the Franciscan Care & Rehab Center on Meade Street in Appleton, Wisconsin.

She was born on July 4, 1914, in Appleton, Wisconsin. She was the daughter of Fredricka (Meltz) Mauthe and Ignatious Mauthe. Sally had one sister Marie and three brothers: Ted, Harry and George (all deceased).

Sally married Joseph J. Ebben on September 20, 1934. Joseph died on July 5, 1981. They had a daughter, JoAnn (Ken) Heuring, Appleton; Kathy (David) Ottman, Appleton, great-grandchildren, Daniel and Cory; David (Tamerine Cornelius) Heuring, Madison, WI; great-grandchild, Stella; Ann (Eric) Moen, Lodi, WI; great-grandchildren: Zack, Janay, Alec; Jane Heuring, Appleton, WI; great-grandchild, Lucy Heuring Blank; and John (Tracy) Heuring, Appleton, WI; four sons: Ronald (Roxanne) Ebben,Tallahassee, FL; Richard Ebben, Phoenix, AZ; and Steven Ebben, Germany; great-grandchildren, Lisa and Tony; son, Victor (Joan) Ebben of Sherwood, WI, Daniel (Tammy) Ebben, Combined Locks, WI; great-grandchildren: Bradi, Bryna and Danica: Timothy (Emi) Ebben, W. Palm Beach, FL; Scott (Tammy) Ebben, Sherwood, WI; great-grandchildren, Payton and Sutten: son, Joel (Lanny) Ebben of Olathe, KS; Kevin (Heather) Ebben, Plymouth, MN; great-grandchild, Hunter; Greg (Carrie) Ebben, Olathe, KS; and son, Gary (Gail Omernick) Ebben of Plover, WI; Michael (Amy) Ebben, Chicago, IL; and step-grandchildren, Chad (Mary) Groholski, Wauwatosa, WI; Kelly Groholski (deceased). She was blessed with 15 great-grandchildren ... and counting. Sally was a loving Mother / Grandmother / Great-Grandmother and will be greatly missed by her children and their families. We were all so lucky to have her in our lives for so long.

She is at peace and with God now.

Sally was active all of her life and was living independently until just eight weeks ago. She was past president of the Catholic War Veterans Auxiliary, Secretary of St. Therese's Christian Mothers, Elks Auxiliary Member, Advisory Member of the Thompson Senior Center and sang in their chorus, active with the YMCA for 18 years and a member of the Ridgeway Country Club. Sally was an avid bowler and won many trophies at the Elks Club. Sally retired from Gimbels in 1981. She also was a life long Cubs Fan and waited a lifetime for them to win a World Series, but she couldn't wait any longer.

Posted November 3, 2006

Jeanquart, Todd D.

Todd Jeanquart's students at Appleton East High School were amazed when asked to stand on their desks when delivering answers to his questions. Hands waved frantically as students sought the opportunity to speak under unusual but playful conditions. This unique approach to teaching demonstrates what made Todd such an extraordinary and memorable person.

Todd was born on Valentine's Day 1965, in Sturgeon Bay, WI, to loving parents Dale and Joan Jeanquart. He grew up with siblings DJ, Chris and Wendy. At the age of 15, Todd met his future wife and best friend, Heidi, at a middle school dance in Sturgeon Bay. After nine years of dating, they were married in 1990, and made a home together in Appleton.

Todd received his bachelor degree in Journalism and Public Relations from the University of WI Oshkosh. While working in the advertising industry, he began coaching football at Appleton East High School. This opportunity inspired him to leave his job and obtain a teaching degree from Lawrence University. He became an English teacher in the Appleton School district and was currently teaching at Einstein Middle School. While teaching, Todd instilled a passion for writing and poetry in his students. The kids at Einstein Middle School adored Todd's Poetry Cafe where they shared their own creative writings and explored modern song lyrics while surrounded by lava lamps and Christmas lights.

In addition to teaching, Todd expressed his creative talents through his devotion to gardening as well as his prized koi ponds. The countless hours spent in his yard gave Todd great pleasure. Todd also shared an interest in antiquing which at times became a competitive game with Heidi while searching for treasures at estate sales and flea markets. Together they enjoyed travel, the arts and spending time with their dogs.

Todd ended his battle with Leukemia on October 3l, 2006. He was 41 years young. Todd will be forever remembered by his family, friends and those whose lives he touched.

A celebration of Todd's life will be held on Wednesday, November 8, at the Grand Meridian located at 2621 North Oneida Street in Appleton. The celebration will begin at 5 p.m. There will be an opportunity to share stories and poems at 7 p.m. Please come share your memories.

In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund in Todd's name has been established to benefit the students in the Appleton School District.

Jacques, Mark P. (Bumper)

Luke Zimmerman

Sgt. Luke J. Zimmerman, 24, Luxemburg, was killed on Friday, October 27, 2006, in Iraq.

Luke was born May 28, 1982, in Green Bay, to Wesley Zimmerman and Claire (Denissen) Dombrowski. He was a graduate of Luxemburg-Casco High School, Class of 2000.

Luke is survived by his mother, Claire (Denissen) and Richard B. Dombrowski Jr., who filled the role of his absent biological father and treated Luke as his own child since Luke was in the third grade. He is further survived by his brother, Leonardo C. Zimmerman, of Green Bay; and his two stepsisters, Brooke M. Dombrowski, Green Bay; and Toni L. Dombrowski, Little Suamico. Also surviving are maternal grandfather, Alfred Denissen, Green Bay; uncles and aunts, Michael and Rose Denissen, Robert and Christine Belport, Green Bay; Scott and Linda Denissen, Kentucky; Dean and Julie Hoegger, Sturgeon Bay; Kurt and Monica Denissen, Milwaukee; Donald and Katherine Brosig, Green Bay; loving cousins; and stepgrandmother, Rosemary Gag-non, Green Bay.

He was preceded in death by his maternal grandmother, Mary Denissen; and paternal grandmother, Patricia Zimmerman.

Luke loved his family and was immensely proud of being in the U.S. Marine Corps. He always was so full of energy and pep, so kind and willing to help, share, and just goof off. He enjoyed his time just being Luke, from his video games, to his little corny trinkets, to all his activities outside the home. He lettered in wrestling, track and cross country, going to Team State with his wrestling pals and also medaling in track at La Crosse with his exceptional relay teams. He also gave football a shot in his underclassman year and completed the season dutifully because quitting mid-season was not an accepted option (even though it wasn't his forte').

Luke worked tirelessly at Julie's Caf, all the while engaged in a full slate of extra-curricular sports. He never complained and rarely, if ever, missed his work assignment. Luke was so committed to the Marine Corps that he made his mind up in the seventh grade. He joined the program for early enlistment and left almost immediately after graduation. He re-enlisted after his first four-year tour. He enjoyed his job at the U.S. Embassy in Austria. He then had 18 months left to serve while stationed at Quantico, Va., but wasn't able to accept other Marines doing what he felt Marines were supposed to do. So he selflessly volunteered to join the unit that was going to be deployed to Iraq. Luke enlisted in the infantry and expected to be a warrior and wanted to live up to the standards of a man and a Marine. We believe he achieved those milestones. Luke was passionately known as "the mule" by his Marine comrades, and those who personally knew him can relate to that. Luke and his family kept all service members, and especially U.S. Marines as equals. No one Marine was esteemed over another (maybe Chesty). Luke was so proud to have received his Combat Action Ribbon and his Iraqi Campaign Service Medal. In addition to being decorated with a Purple Heart, Luke's service ribbons included the Marine Corps Good Conduct Medal with one star in lieu of a second award, War on Terrorism Service Medal, Navy Unit Commendation Navy/Marine Corps and the Navy Sea Service Deployment Ribbon with three Bronze Star Devices, and the National Defense Service Medal.

Luke's parents and brother were blessed by the Lord to have him for 24-plus years. When notified, one of his mother's biggest worries was if other Marines got injured. Luke's parents would like to attempt to thank Steve and Julie Metzler and their sons, Scott, Troy, Greg and Eric, for almost unofficially "adopting" Luke. They spent countless times with their buddy and co-worker. Luke loved "The Metzlers" and the feeling was unequivocally reciprocal. Special thanks also to Captain T.M. Mitchell, U.S.M.C. and Corporal Stigsell for doing an exceptional job in assisting Luke's mom with what the Marines do best - taking care of their own. Semper Fidelis. Pastor William Kamke and the parishioners of the Robinsonville Presbyterian Church of New Franken have been so kind, compassionate and accommodating.

Friends may call at Proko-Wall Funeral Home, Green Bay, on Friday, November 4, from 3 to 8 p.m. Visitation will continue on Saturday at Robinsonville Presbyterian Church, corner of Doris Rd. and Cty. Rd. K, from 9 a.m. until the time of service. Funeral service will be at 10:30 a.m. at the church, with Pastor William Kamke officiating. Fittingly, Sergeant ZIMMERMAN, Luke J., U.S.M.C. will be laid to rest at Arlington National Cemetery, marking the last chapter in a noble young man's life. Affirmative, over and out.

In lieu of other expressions of sympathy, a memorial fund has been established in Luke's name. On-line condolences may be sent to Luke's family at www.prokowall.com.

Posted November 9, 2006

Lefebvre, Jean Martin

Jean Martin Lefebvre, age 97, died on November 6, 2006, in Spring Green, Wisconsin. She was the last of "the Martin girls," strong, independent and Irish. She was born on September 7, 1909, in Green Bay, Wisconsin, to Joseph and Mildred (Wright) Martin. She was educated at St. Joseph Academy and Rosary College, where the Prohibition "Gin Joints" of Greater Chicago, especially Cicero, Illinois, held more interest than her studies. She was the genuine article, a "flapper," and remained one until the end. In 1934, she married Dr. Edward J. Lefebvre. His 1946 cancer diagnosis led to a decade of struggle and sadness. She was widowed in 1956. Her Irish spirit, her strength, her determination never to complain enabled her to enter the work force, to care for her children and to create great friendships. She enjoyed a distinguished career with the Green Bay Board of Education, retiring in 1971. She instilled in her children a work ethic, a sense of history and a love for language and literature. She also played a mean game of bridge with the same group of women for more than 40 years. She was the toughest player at the table, her cards, her cigarettes and her brandy at her side, her stories animating the evenings. She was the real deal. She was an affectionate mother and grandmother whose love of monkeys delighted everyone. With her grandchildren, she set the pace, playing Candyland to win.

Jean is survived by her son Mark (Marian) of Madison, Wisconsin; a daughter Julie (Robert) of Paughquat, New York, many grandchildren and great-grandchildren, in particular, Elizabeth Wright Lefebvre and Daniel Martin Lefebvre whose home and cats she shared for years. She is also survived by the Lefebvre nieces and nephews and one Martin nephew, James Delaney.

She was preceded in death by her parents; her sisters, Mildred, Florence and Helen; her husband; her beloved son, Steven, who died in 2005; and two grandsons, Steven and Joseph Mirsberger. She was also preceded in death by her lifelong friend, Bernadine Neuman Vander Zanden. They grew up together, married college roommates and were pals in the way bright, funny, independent women of their generation could be.

Jean will be buried with her family in Allouez Cemetery. At her request, there will be no funeral. There will be a brief graveside service on Saturday, November 11, 2006, at 11:00 a.m. She is now back in the old neighborhood where she began her amazing journey. May choirs of angels sing thee to thy rest, Nonnie. The family would like to thank the entire staff of Greenway Manor who so wonderfully cared for Jean since the day she entered their community in 1999.

Memorials in Jean's memory, to advance medical research, can be made to the University of Wisconsin Foundation, 1848 University Avenue, Madison, Wisconsin 53726.

Survivors include his wife of 56 years, Audrey; three children, Kevin (Janice) Mura, Minde (Charles) Peters, and Terry Mura; five grandchildren, Aaron (Kelly) Mura, Christopher (Angelina) Mura, Kenneth Mura, Nathan (Nicole) Peters and Audra Peters (fiance, Tom Schlender); and 10 great-grandchildren.

In addition to his parents, Ray was preceded in death by one granddaughter, Angel Peters; six sisters, Gertrude, Nora, Elaine, Mary, LaVerne and Patricia; and one infant brother.

Friends may call from 4 p.m. to 8 p.m. Thursday, Nov. 9 (TODAY), at Lyndahl Funeral Home. Visitation continues after 1:30 p.m. Friday at Redeemer Lutheran Church, 210 S. Oneida St., where funeral services will be held at 2:30 p.m. officiated by Rev. Paul Pett. Interment in Nicolet Memorial Gardens. Online condolences may be expressed at www.lyndahl.com.

In lieu of other expressions of sympathy, a memorial fund has been established.

Ray's family would like to express their gratitude to Dr. Gerald Bayer and the staff of Green Bay Oncology as well as the "angels" of Unity hospice, especially Shannon, Linda, Mary and Holly.

Baenen, Bette J.

Bette J. Baenen, 56, Oconto Falls, died Wednesday morning, Nov. 8, 2006, at home following a 12-year courageous battle with breast cancer. She was born Jan. 16, 1950, in Oconto Falls to Lyle and Lila (Ziegelbauer) Wolff.

Bette grew up in Oconto Falls where she attended public schools, graduating from high school with the Class of 1968. In 1969, she married Norman Bushman and the couple had three daughters together. Bette lived in Oconto Falls for all of her life where she worked as a CNA at Sharpe Care for many years.

On Aug. 17, 1985, she married John "Jake" Baenen at Grace Lutheran Church in Oconto Falls. Bette enjoyed spending time with her children, grandchildren and family and attending her grandchildren's sporting events. She loved crocheting Afghans for everyone she knew and donated all the handcrafted items she made to friends, family and the residents of the nursing home. Bette will always be remembered by all who knew her for her caring and generous ways of helping others and as "the best Mother a daughter could ever ask for."

Survivors are her three daughters, Donna (Dan) Harris, Debbie (Greg Senn) Vandenlangenberg, Denise Laurent, all of Oconto Falls; her parents, Lyle and Lila Wolff, Oconto Falls; five grandchildren, Denae, Christopher, Alex, Kamin and Jayden; one sister, Nancy (Wally) Weiss, Oconto Falls; two nieces, Laura (Tim) Graef and Lisa (Cory) Bailey; her lifelong and best friend, Kathy Thompson.

She was preceded in death by her husband, John "Jake" Baenen on Oct. 5, 2005; her in-laws, Edward and Edna Baenen; maternal grandparents, Marie and Arthur Ziegelbauer; and her paternal grandparents, Gertrude and Eddie Wolff.

Friends may call at Jones Funeral Service (920-848-2222 or visit: www.jonesfuneral.com) in Oconto Falls from 4 until 8 p.m. Friday, Nov. 10, 2006. Visitation will continue on Saturday morning, Nov. 11, 2006, at the funeral home after 9 a.m. until the time of services. Funeral services will be held 10:30 a.m. Saturday at the funeral home with the Rev. Doreen Jeffers officiating. Burial will follow in Brookside Cemetery, town of Pensaukee, with Greg Senn, Cory Bailey, Tim Graef, Wally Weiss, Kathy Thompson and Trudy Stoeger serving as Bette's pallbearers.

The family of Bette Baenen would like to express their appreciation to Green Bay Oncology, Heartland Hospice, Pastor Doreen Jeffers, the members of Grace Lutheran Church for their prayers and to all others who showed their care and concern to them during Bette's illness.

Lawrence "Larry" Lloyd LaViolette

Lawrence L. LaViolette, age 53, a resident of 1618 Clark St., Manitowoc, entered into eternal life on Nov. 7, 2006, at his residence.

Larry was born on June 23, 1953 in Sturgeon Bay, to the late Kenneth and Jane Demmin LaViolette. He graduated from Lincoln High School, with the class of 1971. After high school, Larry served in the U.S. Air Force for four years, and then later served 24 years in the U.S. Naval Reserve.

On Oct. 28, 1978, Larry married Claran Holschbach at St. John's United Church of Christ in Manitowoc. Larry enjoyed spending time fishing and deer hunting, studying finance and researching stocks, history, gardening and fabricating metal for his family and friends. He was an active member of St. John's United Church of Christ in Manitowoc for over 40 years.

Survivors include his wife: Claran, Manitowoc; a daughter: Chandra (Rob) Susedik, Old Bridge, N.J.; two brothers: Loren (Terri) LaViolette, Manitowoc; Lane (Terri) LaViolette, Baraboo; two sisters: Lynn Paulson, Manitowoc; Lori (Duane) Wiegand, Sturgeon Bay; two grandchildren: Ella and Aiden Susedik, Old Bridge, N.J.; his father-in-law and mother-in-law: Thomas and Doris Holschbach; a special aunt: Grace Felten, Manitowoc; also nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends surviving.

The family will greet relatives and friends at the Harrigan Parkside Funeral Home today from 5 until 8 p.m. A prayer service will be led by the Rev. Dr. James Klein at 7:30 p.m. and will be concluded with a video tribute.

The visitation will continue on Saturday, Nov. 11, 2006, at St. John's United Church of Christ, Manitowoc, from 10 a.m. until the time of the funeral service at 11 a.m. The Rev. Dr. James Klein will officiate, with burial to follow at Knollwood Memorial Gardens. Military graveside rites will be accorded by the Vietnam Veterans of America Chapter 731.

The Harrigan Parkside Funeral Home and Cremation Center, N. 11th and St. Clair streets, Manitowoc, is assisting the family with funeral arrangements.

Joly, Helen "Penny" Louise (Capelle)

Helen "Penny" Louise (Capelle) Joly, 88, lifelong resident of Green Bay, died peacefully at a local nursing home on Nov. 9, 2006. Helen filled her children's homes with gorgeous knitted and crocheted afghans and clothing.
